articles.title: Mouse 'midwives' help their pregnant companions give birth
articles.summary: Scientists have observed mice helping each other when they encounter difficulties during birth, prompting a rethink of caregiving among rodents and other animals
articles.content:
Scientists have observed mice helping each other when they encounter difficulties during birth, prompting a rethink of caregiving among rodents and other animals

Adult mice used their paws and mouths to remove pups stuck in a pregnant female’s birth canal Violet J. Ivan/NYU Grossman School of Medicine

Mice seem to assist pregnant females when they get into difficulty giving birth, with experienced mothers being the most helpful. This is thought to be the first official sighting of such assistance in non-primates, and so expands our knowledge of caregiving behaviours across the animal kingdom.

Humans are the only animal known to aid one another consistently during birth, which is a particularly lengthy and painful process in humans because our babies have large heads and must travel down a relatively narrow birth canal. Other primates, such as black snub-nosed monkeys and bonobos, have also been seen helping one another give birth, but only occasionally.

Now, researchers have observed the same behaviour in mice. Robert Froemke at NYU Langone Health in New York City and his colleagues spotted it while recording the brain activity of mice that were giving birth as part of a separate study. They found that other mice in the same cage interacted with these animals, and it seemed that they were sometimes assisting with pup delivery.

To learn more, the researchers genetically engineered pregnant mice to lack oxytocin receptors. Oxytocin, often called the “love hormone”, induces uterine contractions that help to push mouse pups out of the birth canal. Without these contractions, they are likely to get stuck and die. The mother often won’t survive either.

The researchers housed 10 of these mice in individual cages, pairing each one with a female mouse that had previously given birth to at least one litter. A separate group of seven pregnant mice without oxytocin receptors were kept in individual cages by themselves.

During labour, the mouse mothers assisted the pregnant mice when their pups became stuck. “She will come over and act like a little mouse midwife and very carefully, with her mouth and with her paws, pull the pup out,” says Froemke, who presented the findings at a meeting of the Society for Neuroscience in San Diego, California. The assisting mice also broke open the fluid-filled sac encasing the newborns, allowing them to breathe.

Nine of the 10 pregnant mice that were paired with these mouse “midwives” survived labour, and about 90 per cent of their litters did too, on average. In comparison, only one of the solitary pregnant mice survived giving birth, and all of the pups in this group died. “There are a lot of reasons mammals are social, and a primary reason is to help each other out, especially in these really vulnerable periods,” says Froemke. “Even mice struggle with childbirth and childcare, like we do, and can help others out so it isn’t so traumatic, maybe kind of like we do.”

To assess whether the presence of a mouse who had previously given birth was required, the team placed another 14 pregnant mice without oxytocin receptors in separate cages. Seven of them were paired with male mice, four with female mice who had never given birth and three with female mice that hadn’t all given birth but did also lack oxytocin receptors. In addition to their role in uterine contraction, these receptors are thought to be important for social interactions.

Survival rates generally improved when other mice lent a helping hand Violet J. Ivan/NYU Grossman School of Medicine

The researchers found that nearly 60 per cent of pregnant mice housed with male mice and half of those housed with non-mother females survived labour. But these animals didn’t pull the pups out during delivery. Instead, the males mounted the pregnant female, which placed pressure on her back, helping to push the pups out. Meanwhile, the non-mother females groomed pregnant females and similarly applied abdominal pressure. It is unclear why there is a difference in approach between the groups. Among the three mice kept with females that lacked oxytocin receptors, only one survived.

None of the pups in this part of the experiment survived, however, as their fluid-filled sacs were left intact. “It seems that the experience of being a mother is required to be a successful [mouse] midwife,” says Froemke.

The findings support the idea that caregiving is more common in the animal kingdom than we thought. For instance, mice have been seen giving a form of first aid to their unconcious companions. The latest results suggest that birth and rearing young are “central organising forces in animals’ relations and social networks”, says Froemke.

“Parental care is one of the most influential social interactions,” says Bianca Jones Marlin at Columbia University in New York. These results emphasise that it “requires support”.

Froemke suspects midwife-like behaviors occur among wild mice, and possibly among other rodents and animals in general. “Giving birth is the most vulnerable time in an animal’s life,” he says. “Animals secrete away so as not to be found by predators, which I think is why field observers have rarely seen this in any species other than humans.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery of caregiving behavior during birth in mice, expanding understanding of social and parental care in animals beyond primates. This finding has broad implications for biology and animal behavior, highlighting the importance of social support during vulnerable life stages and potentially influencing future research in animal welfare and social neuroscience.
articles.personality_title: Mice help each other give birth, showing surprising teamwork
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long known that humans and some primates help each other during childbirth, but it was unclear if other animals did the same. Giving birth can be difficult and dangerous, so support from others can be very important.

**What happened** – Researchers at New York University discovered that mice also help each other during birth. They saw experienced mother mice using their paws and mouths to help pregnant mice deliver pups that were stuck. The helpers even broke open the sacs around newborn pups so they could breathe. This was observed during experiments with mice that were genetically changed to have trouble giving birth.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have officially seen such midwife-like behavior outside of primates. The presence of helper mice greatly improved the survival of both mothers and pups. This discovery shows that caregiving and social support during birth might be more common in animals than previously thought, changing how we understand animal social behavior.

**What’s next step** – Researchers want to study if this kind of help happens in wild mice and other animals. They also want to understand why only experienced mother mice can act as midwives, while others provide different kinds of support. This could lead to new insights into animal care and social bonding.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, scientists have found that mice help each other give birth, revealing unexpected teamwork and care among animals during this vulnerable time.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des souris s’entraident pour accoucher, révélant un travail d’équipe surprenant
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques savaient que les humains et certains primates s’aident pendant l’accouchement, mais on ne savait pas si d’autres animaux faisaient de même. Accoucher peut être difficile et dangereux, donc le soutien d’autrui est important.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de New York ont découvert que les souris s’aident aussi pendant la naissance. Ils ont vu des mères expérimentées utiliser leurs pattes et leur bouche pour aider les souris enceintes à sortir des petits coincés. Les aides ont même ouvert les sacs autour des nouveau-nés pour qu’ils puissent respirer. Cela a été observé lors d’expériences avec des souris modifiées génétiquement ayant des difficultés à accoucher.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que des scientifiques observent officiellement ce comportement de sage-femme en dehors des primates. La présence des souris aidantes a beaucoup amélioré la survie des mères et des petits. Cette découverte montre que les soins et le soutien social lors de la naissance sont peut-être plus fréquents chez les animaux qu’on ne le pensait, changeant notre compréhension du comportement social animal.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs veulent étudier si cette aide existe chez les souris sauvages et d’autres animaux. Ils veulent aussi comprendre pourquoi seules les mères expérimentées peuvent jouer ce rôle, tandis que d’autres offrent un soutien différent. Cela pourrait apporter de nouvelles connaissances sur les soins et les liens sociaux chez les animaux.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Pour la première fois, les scientifiques ont découvert que les souris s’aident pour accoucher, révélant un travail d’équipe et des soins inattendus chez les animaux durant ce moment vulnérable.
articles.personality_title_es: Los ratones se ayudan a dar a luz, mostrando un trabajo en equipo sorprendente
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos sabían que los humanos y algunos primates se ayudan durante el parto, pero no estaba claro si otros animales hacían lo mismo. Dar a luz puede ser difícil y peligroso, por lo que el apoyo de otros es importante.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Nueva York descubrieron que los ratones también se ayudan durante el parto. Vieron que las madres con experiencia usaban sus patas y boca para ayudar a las ratonas embarazadas a sacar a las crías atascadas. Las ayudantes incluso rompían las bolsas que rodean a los recién nacidos para que pudieran respirar. Esto se observó en experimentos con ratones modificados genéticamente que tenían problemas para dar a luz.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que los científicos observan oficialmente este comportamiento de partera fuera de los primates. La presencia de ratones ayudantes mejoró mucho la supervivencia de las madres y las crías. Este descubrimiento muestra que el cuidado y el apoyo social durante el parto podrían ser más comunes en los animales de lo que se pensaba, cambiando nuestra comprensión del comportamiento social animal.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores quieren estudiar si este tipo de ayuda ocurre en ratones salvajes y otros animales. También quieren entender por qué solo las madres con experiencia pueden actuar como parteras, mientras que otras brindan diferentes tipos de apoyo. Esto podría llevar a nuevos conocimientos sobre el cuidado y los vínculos sociales en los animales.

**Resumen en una frase** – Por primera vez, los científicos encontraron que los ratones se ayudan a dar a luz, revelando un trabajo en equipo y cuidado inesperados entre animales durante este momento vulnerable.
